ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments:
Recorded lecture
Live virtual lecture
Office hours
N/a
Some live virtual lectures
N/A
introductory R session, office hours, review sessions
The first half of the semester was recorded lectures with live office hours during class time. The second half of the course (101) was live synchronous lectures that were recorded.
Students had the choice of attending sessions virtually or viewing a recorded lecture at their own convenience.
Optional Live virtual lecture

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about ANOVA tests, regression, non-parametric tests, likelihood, model selection, and hypothesis testing and how to perform the majority of these in the computer program R.
I learned basic statistical methods and modeling. This includes topics ranging from z-scores, to confidence intervals, to ANOVA regression.

I learned rudimentary R, basic statistical tests (t-test, chi-squared, regression, ANOVA, GLMs, etc.), and basic stastic principle (Central Limit Theorem, probability, distributions, confidence intervals).
I learned basic understanding of statistical analysis of data set. Also learned how to use R and minutabas.
I had no prior knowledge of statistics, so I learned a lot about the basics of statistical analysis/reasoning (regression, ANOVA, experimental design, etc)
I learned important introductory statistics concepts like probability, parametric and non-parametric functions and how to code with R.
Introduction to statistical tests involving two or more data sets, R coding, rudimentary model building and testing

I learned about different types of distributions, probabilities, general linear model, ANOVA, and generalized linear models. I was introduced to some basic R coding skills for data analysis and visualization.
I learned the basics of ANOVA, regression, and how to use R. I better learned how to read and analyze statistical data.
I gained a strong foundation in basic statistical analysis, including a familiarity with relevant concepts, techniques, approaches, and terminology.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths:
-Includes study of datasets in R, which is a big help for biology majors
-The professor highlights several projects he has led, and it is always fun to see real examples of the material in a prof's research
Weaknesses:
-Expectations for HW assignments were not always clear; several HW questions were not clearly worded
-The format of the final exam was not released until right before the exam.

I felt that sometimes the homework problem sets could have been a bit more clear on what they were looking for in their answers, such as any specific points they wanted us to consider (at least in the beginning so that we know what to do for the future).

Strengths: the course is very well organized and operates super effectively online, the test are very fair and the TAs and course instructors are great. There's plenty of office hours in the first half since they are so many TA's for this course. Once you get to the individual section there are less TA's but I didn't find an issue with scheduling. For my individual section, I was initially apprehensive about learning R since I have never coded before, but it is not a steep learning curve at all. They provide scripts which make the process a lot easier. 
Weakness: Sometime in the second half (Life Science section) I found the material a little repetitive but this wasn't a big deal for me at all as I really ended up understanding the concept.
Strength is how many office hours are offered. Weakness is I dont like stats but I think that is personal issue of not liking math.

I appreciate all the effort instructors and TAs put into the course this semester (with all of this year's complications and obstacles especially!). The main difficulties I experienced were related to the online format (which I understand was necessitated by the pandemic), so I don't really have any suggestions for improvement.
The homework assignments were helpful in revealing what I did and didn't understand. The lectures were generally well organized and there were plenty of office hours.

strengths - homework closely modeled lectures, allowing you to explore tests on your own but also have a safety net to rely on if you're lost
use of other media for learning, e.g DataCamp exercises in R
homework sets had more points as the course went on and your understanding of the concepts developed

weaknesses - homework assignments (2) with a DataCamp component were disproportionately long and did not reflect the point value of the assignment as much
lecture slides with R codes and responses were sometimes hard to read (text too small)
no real opportunity to work with fellow students

I loved the first half of the semester with Jonathan. His sense of humor made the recorded lectures engaging. The vast amount of office hour available was amazing. Jonathan himself is great with explaining and patiently re-explaining concepts during his live office hours during class time, and there are also so many tutor hours anyone who wish to seek help definitely should have been able to have a time that works for them. The second half of the semester (splitting into our respective sections) was good. The professor and TF understood that many students hadn't had previous exposure to R before and explains everything really nicely. I never felt stressed entering into the 2nd half not knowing anything about R, because the support was there and things explained during lecture. The class doesn't assume previous knowledge.

In terms of content and teaching I believe that this course was effective. I do wish that the teacher went a little slower in terms of giving out information, but it is made up for by the recorded sessions. However, I felt more inclined to view recordings than attend lectures live because of this.

The course has strong lecture material and good system of quizzes to help you keep track of the material. The content is approachable for students with no prior background in statistics. There is an array of resources available to provide assistance, and the course is structured in a logical and understandable way that gradually builds up to complicated material.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: See above regarding recorded lectures. Office hours were also excellent. However, the fact that the format of the final was not released until right before the test brought undue stress upon myself and other students in the class. I'd appreciate it for the sake of students coming after me if the format was finalized much earlier so we could study accordingly.
The recorded lectures were helpful, especially if I wanted to review a topic. Also, having a lot of office hours was helpful for the problems sets or clarifying a question.
This course was very understanding of the pandemic.
I appreciated that all lectures and slides were recorded and posted on Canvas - this was so helpful to me in reviewing/studying.
The high number of office hours helped. I appreciated having the freedom throughout my days to decide what times worked best for my schedule to go seek help.

Homework assignments very useful for applying the material learned in lecture and in DataCamp
Open-note exams allowed for best performance on exam

Make lecture text with R code and responses larger
Encourage more engagement by group work between students

The huge amount of office hours (I'm not sure if during pre-COVID times if there are also this many hours available) was definitely a godsend for this class. I don't feel like learning remotely negatively impacted my learning for this class, since there are plenty of opportunities to engage live with a tutor/the professors, even if time zones are bad for you. Having such a big support system really helped. I honestly don't know if this class would be better taught in person than remotely like this semester.
The course gave opportunities for both live watching and recorded watching which created no problems.

The wide range of tutoring help and assistance was wonderful, as was the system of date-flexible quizzes. I think that additional steps should be taken to clarify the purpose and usage of Piazza, which could become crowded with off-topic inquiries.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It seems to be among the most reasonable statistics courses for folks without extensive backgrounds, so if you're new to stats take this. Otherwise, not unless it's for your major.

Yes, I would recommend this course. I'd never taken a statistics course before, so I felt that this course was a very good introduction into this field and it provided a lot of basic, crucial knowledge for understanding statistics.

Yes totally. It's pretty low stress and the amount of workload is completely fair. The first half was very well organized and structured-- the Professor is one of the best lecturers I've ever seen and makes stats actually interesting. For the Life Sciences section, everything was really explained and I left actually absorbing the information despite mostly watching the lecture videos. And if the R scares you, it's not a big deal and I found it super approachable as someone whose never touched coding before.
I would not but only because I do not like stats. If someone said they loved math or stats I absolutely would. The TFs were all great along with professors.
Yes, I would - I liked the instructors and, although the course was difficult for me at times, I feel that I came away from it having developed a good foundation of statistical knowledge.
I would recommend this course, even if you have never taken a statistics course before.

Yes! This course gives you an intro into statistical methods that you could very well come across in E&EB and related research, as well as help you understand the statistics used in scientific papers you read!

Yes, this is a good intro to stats class, worthwhile to take even if you have taken stats in high school before, I think. There are definitely plenty of topics that I encountered for the first time in this class, even though I did take stats in high school. Maybe this class would be too easy for stats/math majors looking for something more advanced, but as a non-math major, I felt like this course was paced fairly and the workload wasn't too much. You have to put in a certain amount of work, but it wasn't stressful, and there's a strong support system. 101 was also fair and a good class to gain experience with R. I had never worked with R or other coding languages before (which was why I selected 101), and I prepared myself for a learning curve in the beginning of the second half, but it was actually completely painless. 101 didn't assumed prior R knowledge, and everything was explained, so I had a good time.

I would recommend this course highly to students with no prior statistics background. This course makes statistics seem much less daunting and provides a small army of tutors and assistants to help you master the material. I did not expect to enjoy this course as much as I did, and even got me interested in taking more stats classes because it showed me the capabilities and strength of programs like R for answering complicated questions.
